metadata.title: Quantum Gravity In One Dimension. Why Quantum Gravity in 1D Describes… | by Marco Tavora Ph.D. | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: Quantum gravity can be said to be the Holy Grail of theoretical physics. Though a thoroughly developed theory of quantum gravity is still beyond our grasp, physicists believe that it might contain…

all_paragraphs: Quantum gravity can be said to be the Holy Grail of theoretical physics. Though a thoroughly developed theory of quantum gravity is still beyond our grasp, physicists believe that it might contain some essential ingredients. In this article, I will show that the theory of quantum gravity in one dimension also describes particles in four-dimensional spacetime.

One such ingredient is the Feynman sum-over-histories formalism. The latter expresses the transition amplitude (or propagator) as a weighted sum of all possible spacetime paths of the system from some initial state to some final state. In the context of quantum gravity, the average in the path integral is not over paths in spacetime but over geometries of spacetimes (however, as pointed out in Witten, this description may be invalid at the microscopical level).
You can see my last article for more details about the sum-over-histories approach to quantum mechanics.

To establish the correspondence between one-dimensional quantum gravity and quantum field theory (QFT) in four-dimensional spacetime, we first need to understand each of these two ingredients. Let us start with the latter. The methodology followed here is often referred to as the worldline perspective of QFT (see Skinner lectures).
Quantum fields are extensions of classical fields, such as the electromagnetic field and Einstein’s gravitation field, to the quantum framework.
In Zee the author defines quantum field theory as follows:
“Quantum field theory is a response to the ephemeral nature of life.”
This definition comes from the following observation: combining special relativity and quantum mechanics implies that particles “can be born and die”.

Let us understand why. The energy-time uncertainty principle states that one cannot determine the energy of quantum states that only exist for brief periods of time. Mathematically this is expressed by:
In fact, vacuum energy fluctuates violently as illustrated below, allowing the creation of pairs of (particle-antiparticle) virtual particles.

As a consequence of special relativity, this leads to the possible conversion of energy into mass: new particles can be “born”, and existing particles can “disappear”. The problem is that the standard quantum mechanical framework cannot explain this phenomenon, and consequently, needs to be modified. This modified version of quantum mechanics is QFT.
Furthermore, QFT enables us to explain, among other things, why there are indistinguishable copies of elementary particles in the Universe: particles are merely excitations of quantum fields.

Quantum fields are rather abstract. Following several treatments of the subject, I will, to give some intuition to the reader, use the analogy of a string of N harmonic oscillators with mass m coupled to each other. Only vertical qᵢ(t) displacements will be considered.
The corresponding action of the is:
where the matrix M is symmetric and positive-definitive:
Diagonalizing M we obtain the action for the normal modes:
The ωs are the eigenfrequencies with which the masses oscillate.

The next step is to obtain the action for a continuum scalar classical field ϕ(x,t). The scalar field the simplest type of field in QFT. A useful way to interpret ϕ(x,t) is as an infinite set of oscillators at each point x (see Mukhanov and Winitzki). Note that the oscillators’ indexes i become the spatial coordinate x when we take the continuum limit. The action in the continuum limit becomes:
According to the path integral formulation of quantum mechanics, the probability for a system to make the transition between two states I and F is
where the Lagrangian density, in this case, is given by:

The generating functional or partition function, a specific case of Eq. 6 and a key object in quantum field theory, is the transition amplitude from the vacuum state back to itself, and it is given by:
The vacuum state is illustrated in Fig. 4 above.

Aside About Quantization SchemesIn this article, I will follow the path integral method of quantization (instead of the canonical one). As we just saw, this method is based on the Lagrangian which is relativistically invariant making the path integral also manifestly invariant. Furthermore, the objects inside the integral are classical quantities (this is highly convenient since in this formulation there aren’t annoying non-commutating operators, for example).

We note that the method involves a shift in perspective when compared to the canonical quantization. The Hamiltonian dynamics of the system is defined by Eq. 6 (see Peskin). Therefore the Lagrangian becomes the “most fundamental specification” of quantum field theory (see Peskin).
Let us return to Eq. 4 for the real scalar field theory. The Euler-Lagrangian equations of motion are obtained applying the steepest descent method approximation to the action:
The result is the ubiquitous Klein-Gordon equation:
Rewriting the Lagrangian explicitly we get, for Eq. 8:

where an external potential or source current J was included. The term containing J is a potential energy term associated with the interaction between the scalar field ϕ(x) and the source current J(x).
This integral is just a complicated version of the trivial Gaussian integral:
and can be evaluated using the standard procedures of Gaussian integration. We obtain:
The function D(x) is the free propagator, which is a solution of the following differential equation:
From Eq. 13, we can calculate the Feynman propagator in momentum space for a particle with momentum p, which is the object multiplying the exponential in the integrand for D(x-y) below:

where the ε is a small positive quantity. Up to know, a silent assumption is that we are work in the Lorentzian signature. The signature of a given spacetime is the number of positive and negative values on the matrix representation of the metric tensor after diagonalization. For an n-dimensional Lorentzian manifold,
If instead, we work in Euclidean signature (+,+,…,+), as we shall often in the rest of the article, we lose the ε and the sign before the mass term becomes positive. The propagator then reads:
Let us now dive into the second ingredient of our discussion (see the last paragraph of the introduction), which is quantum gravity in a one-dimension spacetime.
Our goal now is to build a quantum field theory or QFT in one dimension where the fields interact with gravity. As noted by Skinner, to build our QFT we need two basic ingredients:
There are only two possible compact manifolds (closed and bounded manifolds) in one dimension, namely, the circle S¹ and the interval I:

We can label the points of both these manifolds by a real number: the interval I and the circle S¹ can be parametrized by t ∈ [0, T]. The difference is that in S¹, we identify t and t +T (see Skinner). Each manifold has its associated metric g which is, in one dimension, a 1x1 tensor. We denote the metric and the inverse metric respectively by:
The notion of pullback will be briefly introduced in this section for future use.

PullbacksA useful concept from differential geometry is a pullback (see Baez and Muniain and Carroll for more details). Consider the two manifolds M and N, the maps ϕ, f, and their composition, all illustrated in the figure below.
We see that from the figure that
The pullback of the function f from N to M by the function ϕ is defined by the following composite function:
Figure 7 illustrates the process of pulling back f from N to M by the map ϕ.

Now let us denote by (M, g) one of the two one-dimensional manifolds above, namely, the interval I, and let it be the spacetime where the fields “live”. We also introduce another manifold (N, G) with n dimensions. The latter is called target space and is the space of the objects to be studied, namely, the scalar fields (see Skinner).
Now consider a map between these two manifolds
Let us introduce coordinates on N and choose an open patch U ⊂ N with n local coordinates
where for each t ∈ M there is an x(t) in U. Each of the n objects x above is a scalar field (though the standard notation for such fields is ϕʲ, this choice will be more convenient).
The figure below makes these definitions clearer:
Based on the previous discussion we identify the local coordinates xⁱ(t) as pullbacks to M of the coordinates inside the open patch U by the function x.
We will now write down the general relativistic action of our theory. In general, the general relativistic action reads:
In this expression, there are four important quantities:

When we have only one dimension, R vanishes (the intrinsic curvature of a curve does not exist). A consequence of the fact that R ≡ 0 is that, in one dimension, gravity is non-dynamical (see Skinner). The action above for a 1D manifold is much simpler than Eq. 19 and can be written as:
The first term inside the brackets represents the scalar fields where G is the pullback to M of the metric on N. Note the absence of the term

In spite of that, we can still build a theory of quantum gravity where the metric is coupled to the matter fields. The presence of the metric g indicates that the scalar fields interact with gravity. Choosing the Lorentzian metric in the target space
The Einstein field equations (EFE) can be derived from the action if we vary S with respect to g. Defining 2Λ ≡ m² the “EFE” read:
This equation can be written in terms of the “conjugate momenta”:
The reason for the quotation marks is to remind us that the xs are scalar fields and not position coordinates (up to now):
Following the standard process of canonical quantization (and setting ħ = 1)

where we see that the quantum wave function of the system Ψ is annihilated by the differential operator associated with Eq. 24. If we reparametrize the manifold M or equivalently if we perform a general coordinate transformation
the metric tensor transforms as follows:
Now, we can rescale the metric anyway we want. Choosing:
changing the notation from x⁰ to t and setting n=d=4 we obtain the Klein-Gordon equation (KGE):
The KGE describes particles with spin-0. The famous Higgs boson is the first and only observed particle with spin-0.

We conclude that there exists a nontrivial theory of quantum gravity in one-dimension and that it describes the dynamics of a massive particle moving in four-dimensional Minkowski spacetime! Note that in the new interpretation, the scalar fields become spacetime coordinates.

Let us now calculate the transition amplitude (or propagator) for a particle to propagate from a point x to another point y in spacetime. See the left-hand side of Fig. 1 which shows examples of paths contributing to a generic propagator.
For convenience (following Skinner and Witten) we will choose the n-dimensional manifold N to be a four-dimensional Euclidean spacetime with Euclidean metric:
We will evaluate the propagator G also using the Euclidean signature in the one-dimensional manifold M. In the Heisenberg picture the propagator reads:
For a comprehensive discussion of Euclidean spacetime see one of my previous articles:
This expression can be written is given by the following integral:
where T ≡ τ. The propagator at fixed τ can be expressed as a path integral over all possible paths:

In quantum gravity, to calculate the transition amplitude we must perform an additional integration over all possible metrics on the one-dimensional M, up to diffeomorphisms. However, note that the freedom for reparametrization discussed above is limited by the fact that the total length of M is unchanged for arbitrary coordinate transformations:

The length is the only invariant of M. Therefore, integrating over all possible metrics up to diffeomorphisms, in this case, means simply integrating over all possible lengths (which can be interpreted as the proper time). Hence:

Apart from a factor of 2, this is the standard scalar field propagator for a particle with mass m on Euclidean 4-dimensional space we met before. The usual propagator, therefore, can be expressed as an integral over the one-dimensional quantum gravity manifold. We see again that quantum gravity in one dimension also describes spin-0 particles in four-dimensional spacetime. In other words, we can interpret a free particle moving in 4-dimensional spacetime in terms of a quantum gravity theory in one dimension!
As always, thanks for reading, and see you soon! Constructive criticism and feedback are always welcome!
My Github and personal website www.marcotavora.me, have some other cool stuff both about theoretical physics and other topics such as deep learning and finance. Check them out!
